section.title: Introduction
section.para: The onCourse Editor is your platform to create, manage and distribute information to your website. The Editor is a Content Managment System (CMS) that provides simple but powerful tools to manage the struture and content of your website in a collaborative environment.

section.title: Setting up Access to the Editor
section.para: Before you start editing content within the Editor you need to set up a user name and password to log in.

onCourse enables any user to also have the ability to log into and edit content within the Editor using the same log in credentials that you use to access the onCourse Client . To do this go to File > Preferences > Users and open the relevant record, then tick the box 'Can edit CMS'.

caption.para: Enabling Editor Access within onCourse User Profile

section.title: Logging In
section.para: You can access the editor by visiting your name site and adding '#editor' at the end of the url. For example, if your website url is 'http://www.acme.com.au' the editor can be accessed at 'xml http://www.acme.com.au#editor'.

section.title: The Editor View

caption.para: Finding your way around the Editor view

section.para: Once logged in, a new toolbar will be visible o the left hand side of the browser window. You can continue to browse through your site as normal while logged into the Editor.

Across the left of the screen you will find icons that allows you to quickly access the primary areas of the Editor. In addition, you will also see an option to publish any changes you've made to the live site, as well as view a log of all recent changes to the site.

section.title: Editing Content
section.para: Clicking the Content Icon will take you to the editor for Blocks, Pages and Themes. These three components make up the strucutre of the website.

section.title: Blocks
section.para: Blocks are the cornerstone to your website's variety and page dynamics. For example if you wanted an element (a banner for example) on every page of your web site, then blocks are your answer. If you wanted an area on several different pages dedicated to a contact form, blocks are ideal. Blocks are re-usable snippets of text, pictures, rich text markup, javascript, etc.

caption.para: The Blocks page allows you to easily add, search and edit blocks.

section.para: Selecting a block will take you to the Editor page for that specific block. Here, you can change the name of the block, as well as editing it's content. On the righ side of the screen you will see a rendering of what the block will look like on your website

Clicking on the block contents will open the block in a text editor view. Here, you can write markup text or html to be added to the block. Clicking save will close the text editor and render your changes for you to view.

section.title: Pages
section.para:
Many pages generated in your "onCourse" website will be content automatically generated from your Course, Classes, and Tutor descriptions. Some of the pages in your site have URLs like this:
/courses
/courses/arts/photography
/course/ABC
/sites
/tutor/123
/site/234
/checkout

Additionally, you can create 'static' pages to your website. These allows you to add additional content to add breadth and cohesion to your website. For example, you may like to add an "about us" or "contact" page.

The Pages view will list of all the static pages in your site and gives you quick access to search for, edit and delete pages. Similar to the Block view, clicking on a Page will open that Page in a text editor view.

Here, you can change the theme that is applied to this page, the pages name, as well as editting the content of the page. You can also elect whether any given page is 'avaiable'. Pages that are not marked as available can only be accessed with their direct url link. Keep pages that you don't want users stumbling across, or that may be under contruction as 'invisible'.

section.title: Menus
section.para: Most websites will have a primary navigation menu which users will use to find their way around. In this place you can add new menu items, and link them to particular pages or external URLs. The user interface here is very simple: click on the menu name to edit it. The name is visible to users of your website. Drag the menu items into a different order or nest them within other menu items. And click to edit the URL (that is, the page to which the menu links).
Menus exist in a heirarchy. Dropping a menu item onto another will make it part of a submenu.

section.title: Settings
section.para: The onCourse website editor allows users to manage a number of different aspects of how their website and portal displays information. This includes determining the site redirects, what information can be viewed through the Skills onCourse portal and any checkout settings.

section.title: SkillsOnCourse
section.para: The Editor settings page allows Colleges to manage the amount of information that is able to be viewed by Tutors in the Skills onCourse portal. You can also choose whether you want the tutors to be able to mark outcomes in the portal. It is also possible to specify as to which email address tutor feedback is sent to within the College.

When viewing the class roll via the Skills onCourse, Colleges can determine whether they want their tutors to be able to view the email address, phone numbers of each student on the class roll. Please note that it is not possible to not display the contact details for one class, but display it for another, as this setting is universally applied.

See the following screen from the Skills onCourse portal which shows where the student contact details display within the class roll. By specifying that you do not want the contact details to be displayed, this class list would simply show as a list of student names.

section.title: Website Settings
section.para: The Editor gives you access to a powerful social media linking tool called 'Add This'. This free tool will enable a college to insert social media links into courses and web pages, as well as giving you access to analytical tools to gain insight into your audience.

In order to add these social media links, you need to set up a free account with 'Add This', including specifying which social media links you wish to display on your website, the size and format of those links, as well as the free analytics tools that are part of your account set up.

Once you have set up the 'Add This' account by following the link within the Editor, all you need to do to insert the id into the field provided and then specify as to whether you wish these links to appear on your course description and or web page.

section.title: Checkout
section.para: You can customise the checkout process using the editor settings menu.

Here you can set where a student is directed after the enrolment process. In addtion, you can also set a custom page to outline any policies, procedures or terms and conditions a student must adhere to on enrolmnet.

section.title: Redirects
section.para: You have the ability to create 301 redirects to your website by entering the local path in the field on the left (starting with '/') and the destination in the field on the right (either starting with '/' for another local page or starting with http/https for redirecting to another website). Once you have done this simply click on the save button which in turn will add them to the list of redirects below.

section.title: Design
section.para: The Design menu lets you edit the Themes applied to your onCourse website.

section.title: Themes
section.para: Themes are a way to describe a page structure made up by a number of blocks and by a design layout created for you by your designer. There will always be a layout called "default". If you want different parts of your site to have very different looks, ask your designer to create alternative layouts for you to use.

Each theme can have a number of blocks arranged in any way you choose. There are five regions available:
header
left
content
right
footer

Each region can contain one or more blocks which you drag from the right area. To remove a block just drag it back into the list of unused blocks on the right. You can order the blocks on the page by dragging them into the position of your choice. Remember, that when the page is shown the content area will also contain any content for the page itself. The blocks are shown above the page content, although your web designer can change that if they choose.

section.title: Change Log
section.para: Clicking the 'edits' button at the bottom of the right hand Editor bar will navigate to the Change Log. This will display the most recent versions of the site, the date this version of the site was publish and who published this version of the site. You will also see the current version of the site and have the option to publish your changes from this page.

section.title: Reverting Changes
section.para: Each revision of the site has an option to revert the site to this version. Reverting changes will revert the site to how it was on the given date. Reverting changes cannot be undone. To recover your site it will have to be restored from a local backup.

section.title: Publishing your changes
section.para: Any changes you've made are only visbile when logged into the Editor. Your site must be publshed before any changes made in the Editor appear on the live site.

To push your changes to your live site, click on the blue 'Publish' button on the bottom of the Editor sidebar. This will prompt the user to confirm that they want their changes published. Clicking 'Confirm' will commit any changes you have made, and make these changes visible on the live version of your site.
